   Disorderly conduct - see GEN. OFF. 648.04
   Littering - see GEN. OFF. 660.03
   Sidewalk obstructions; damage or injury - see GEN. OFF. 660.10
   Licensing in general - see B. R. & T.
Ch. 804
   810.01   APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   Persons desiring to hold an auction sale shall file a written application
stating, in addition to the requirements of Section 804.03, the name of the
would-be auction seller who for one year previous shall have owned the goods to
be sold, and shall attach thereto an inventory of the stock on hand, and shall
file therewith a certified copy of the required State auctioneer's license.
   810.02   BOND.
   Each applicant for a license to conduct an auction shall file a bond in the
sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2, 500), conditioned upon the
observance of the provisions of this chapter and for the indemnification of any
purchaser at an auction suffering loss by reason of misrepresentation.
(Ord.1130. Passed 6-28-56.)
   810.03   RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   A license to conduct an auction shall not be issued to any person who has
not been continuously engaged in the City as a merchant, dealing in the sale of
goods, wares or merchandise described in the inventory referred to in Section
810.01 for the period of one year next preceding the proposed auction sale, nor
shall such license be issued for an auction sale by a purchaser from a person
who for six months preceding the purchase has not been continuously engaged in
the business upon the same premises where the sale is proposed to be held, and
no such license shall be issued for such an auction if an auction sale has been
held within a period of one year of the time of application for such license.
(Ord.1130. Passed 6-28-56.)
   810.04   LENGTH OF SALES; SUNDAY SALES PROHIBITED.
   Auction sales conducted under the provisions of this chapter shall not
continue for more than a total of thirty continuous days within a year, Sundays
and holidays excepted. No such auction shall be conducted on a Sunday.
(Ord.1130. Passed 6-28-56.)
   810.05   FALSE AND MISLEADING STATEMENTS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall, in the conduct of an auction under the provisions of this
chapter, make false and misleading statements.
(Ord.1130. Passed 6-28-56.)
   810.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section 804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 830
House, Garage or Yard Sales
830.01   License required.
830.02   License fee.
830.03   Limitation on issuance.
830.04   Effective period; display.
830.05   Purpose.
830.06   Posting signs on utility poles.
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate advertising - see Ohio R. C. 715.65
   Soliciting business or employment on a highway - see TRAF.
416.06
   Theft by deception - see GEN. OFF. 642.02(a)(3)
   Disorderly conduct - see GEN. OFF. 648.04
   Littering - see GEN. OFF. 660.03
   Sidewalk obstructions; damage or injury - see GEN. OFF. 660.10
   Licensing in general - see B. R. & T.
Ch. 804
   830.01   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct any sale of household goods and belongings, commonly
described as a house, garage or yard sale, without first having obtained a
license therefor from the Police Chief.
(Ord.68-34. Passed 7-23-68.)
   830.02   LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for the license required in Section 830.01 shall be three dollars
($3.00).
(Ord.82-0-9. Passed 7-27-82.)
   880.03   LIMITATION ON ISSUANCE.
   Issuance of the license required in Section 830.01 shall be confined to one
license per residence in any twelve-month period. The license so issued shall
be effective for twelve months from the date of issuance. Such license shall
entitle the licensee to conduct up to three garage sales during the term of the
license. No one sale shall extend for more than four days.
(Ord.88-0-3. Passed 2-23-88.)
   830.04   EFFECTIVE PERIOD; DISPLAY.
   The license required in Section 830.01 shall expire at the completion of the
licensee's third garage sale. The Police Department shall be notified of the
beginning and ending dates of each sale. Such license shall be conspicuously
displayed on the sale premises during the time of the sale.
(Ord.82-0-9. Passed 7-27-82.)
   830.05   PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is the orderly regulation of traffic and parking
within the City, as well as other Municipal purposes, including the control of
commercial activity within residential neighborhoods and the regulation of
nuisances.
(Ord.68-34. Passed 7-23-68.)
   830.06   POSTING SIGNS ON UTILITY POLES.
   No person shall post a sign advertising a house, garage or yard sale on a
utility pole or other public property.
(Ord.82-0-9. Passed 7-27-82.)
   830.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined
not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For any subsequent offense, such
person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both. In addition, the penalty for a violation of Section
830.06 is the revocation of the current and all future permits.
(Ord.82-0-9. Passed 7-27-82.)
CHAPTER 846
Parades and Open Air Meetings
846.01   Definitions.
846.02   Permit required.
846.03   Permit application; fee.
846.04   Permit application; contents.
846.05   Investigation of application; permit issuance.
846.06   Permit denial; appeals.
846.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Funeral processions - see TRAF.
432.21
   Safety of crowds attending live entertainment performances - see GEN. OFF.
636.18
   Disturbing a lawful meeting - see GEN. OFF. 648.05
   Special events - see B.R. & T. Ch. 864
   846.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Open air meeting" means a congregation of citizens held outdoors and
on public property for the purpose of hearing speakers or discussing some
matter of common interest, where the number of participants expected may
reasonably be assumed to exceed fifty.
   (b)   "Parade" means a parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or
procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or on a street, park or
other public place in the City, with the exception of any parade that is a
"special event parade" as that term is defined in Codified Ordinance Section
864.01(g).
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
   846.02   PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall conduct a parade or open air meeting in or on a public way,
park or playground, without first obtaining a permit therefor, in writing, from
the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
   846.03 PERMIT APPLICATION; FEE.
   A person desiring to hold a parade or an open air meeting shall apply for a
permit by filing with the Chief of Police a written application upon a form
provided for that purpose. Each application must be accompanied by a
nonrefundable application fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The application
for the permit must be made at least sixty days prior to the date scheduled for
the parade or open air meeting.
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
   846.04 PERMIT APPLICATION; CONTENTS.
   An application for such a permit shall set forth the following information:
   (a)   The route along which the parade is to proceed, or the place at which
the meeting is to be held;
   (b)    The time such parade or meeting is to start;
   (c)    The duration of such parade or meeting,
   (d)    The name and address of the person or organization in charge, in
control or responsible for the parade or meeting,
   (e)    The purpose of such parade or meeting; and
   (f)    The approximate number of persons involved in such parade or meeting.
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
   846.05 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICATION; PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   The Chief of Police or an officer delegated by him or her shall forthwith
investigate the person applying for the permit and the truth of the statements
in the application regarding the purpose of the event. The officer in charge of
such investigation shall notify the Chief of Police in writing of his or her
findings. If the findings are that such parade or open air meeting will not be
held for any unlawful purpose, will not in any manner tend to be a breach of
the peace, will not unnecessarily interfere with the use of a public way or
with the peace and quiet of the residents of the City, the Chief of Police
shall issue such permit.
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
   846.06    PERMIT DENIAL; APPEALS.
   If the Chief of Police denies the issuance of such permit, the applicant has
the right to appear before the Mayor and Council at any special or regular
meeting and be heard on all aspects of the application. The Mayor and Council
may confirm the order of the Chief of Police or may overrule the Chief of
Police and order the issuance of the permit.
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
   846.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) and
imprisoned not more than thirty days for each offense. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 94-0-06. Passed 9-27-94.)
CHAPTER 850
Peddlers and Solicitors
   EDITOR’S NOTE: This chapter was repealed and re-enacted in its entirety by
Ordinance 2003-O-04, as amended, and codified herein.
850.01   Definitions.
850.02   Notice prohibiting canvassing or solicitation.
850.03   Canvassing or solicitation in violation of notice.
850.04   Solicitations permitted only during certain hours.
850.05   Canvassing for charitable or religious purposes; interstate/intrastate
commerce; registration required.
850.06   Information required for registration.
850.07   Issuance of registration certificate; transfers; duration.
850.08   Display of registration certificate; return; exceptions.
850.09   Revocation of certificates.
850.10   Door-to-door sales in interstate/intrastate commerce; peddlers;
license required; application.
850.11   Peddlers of frozen desserts.
850.12   Regulations for persons using vehicles.
850.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
   Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
   Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
   License revocation of itinerant vendors, peddlers, etc. - see Ohio R.C.
2961.03
   Soliciting business or employment on a highway - see TRAF.
416.06
   Littering - see GEN. OFF. 660.03
   Sidewalk obstructions; damage or injury - see GEN. OFF. 660.10
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 804
   850.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used int his chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the
context:
   (a)   "Canvassing", "canvasser", "solicitation" and "solicitor" include any
person who calls at residences or places of business without the invitation or
previous consent of the owners or occupants of such premises for the purpose of
any one or more of the following activities:
      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or description
whatever, for either present or future delivery;
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or character;
      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and any other type or kind of publication;
      (4)   Seeking to obtain contributions or to sell any goods, articles or
services of any kind for the support or benefit of any charitable, religious or
nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project;
      (5)   Seeking to obtain, from an occupant of any residence, an indication
of such occupant's belief in regard to any social, political or religious
matter;
      (6)   Seeking to influence the personal belief of the occupant of any
residence in regard to any social, political or religious matter; or
      (7)   Taking a poll or census by any person, firm or corporation other
than a governmental body or agency thereof.
   (b)   "Canvasser for charitable or religious purposes" means any person who
calls at residences or places of business without the invitation or previous
consent of the owners or occupants of such premises for the purpose of
soliciting or receiving contributions or pledges for charitable or religious
purposes, or to offer or attempt to sell, or request a donation for, any
advertisement, advertising space, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine,
merchandise, ticket, token, flag, souvenir, foodstuff, service or any other
article or thing in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable
or religious purpose, or when or where, in connection with any such sale,
donation or contribution, any statement is made that the whole or any part of
the proceeds of any such sale will go to or be donated to any charitable or
religious purpose.
   (c)   "Charitable" includes the words patriotic, philanthropic, social
service, welfare, eleemosynary, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal,
veteran's, medical, and social research, either actual or purported.
   (d)   "Contribution" includes the words gift, food, clothing, money,
property or donations of any kind, including those made under the guise of a
loan or money or property.
   (e)   "Door-to-door salesperson in interstate commerce" means a person who
travels from door-to-door calling on private residences or places of business
in the city for the purpose of taking orders for future delivery of goods or
services to be furnished, supplied or delivered from sources outside the State
and which is not done in connection with any appeal for any charitable or
religious purpose.
   (f)   "Door-to-door salesperson in intrastate commerce" means a person who
travels from door-to-door calling on private residence or places of business in
the city for the purpose of taking orders for future delivery of goods or
services to be furnished, supplied or delivered from sources within the State
and which is not done in connection with any appeal for any charitable or
religious purpose.
   (g)   "Peddler" means any person who sells or offers for sale and immediate
delivery goods or merchandise or services of any kind or description other than
from a fixed and established place of business, including those who sell from
vehicles on the public streets or from goods carried from door-to-door.
   (h)   "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation,
company, association, joint stock company, church, religious sect, religious
denomination, society, organization or league, or any combination of them, and
includes any trustee, member, receiver, assignee, agent or other representative
thereof.
   (i)   "Religious" and "religion" do not include the word "charitable", but
shall be given their commonly accepted definitions.
   (j)   "Religious organization" means any church, body or communicants or
group that is not organized or operated for profit that gathers in common
membership for regular worship and religious observances.
   (k)   "Residence" means every separate living unit occupied for residential
purposes by one or more persons, contained within any building or structure.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.02   NOTICE PROHIBITING CANVASSING OR SOLICITATION.
   (a)   Notice by the owners or occupants of any residence or place of
business of their determination to refuse to receive any uninvited canvassers
or solicitors shall be given by displaying a weatherproof card, decal or sign
not less than three inches by four inches in size, nor more than one square
foot in total surface area, upon or near the main entrance door to the
residence or place of business, indicating such determination by the owner or
occupant, containing the words "No Solicitors Invited" or words to that effect
with the letters at least one-third of any inch in height. Any such sign which
complies with the requirements of this section shall be exempt from any
additional or different requirements contained in the Planning and Zoning Code.
   (b)   (1)   No person shall engage in the activity of canvassing and/or
soliciting at any residence whose owner or occupant has requested of the City
or its designee, in writing, that such owner, occupant or resident desires the
premises to be free from canvassing or soliciting of orders, donations, sales,
subscriptions or business information at residences. The City Administrative
Director or her or his designee shall keep a list for public inspection of all
residences whose owners or occupants have requested, in writing, that they be
kept free from canvassing and/or soliciting.
      (2)   Council and the Administration hereby designate Northeast Ohio
Public Energy Council ("NOPEC") to compile and maintain this list for the City
for as long as NOPEC shall agree to do so. NOPEC shall establish and maintain
for the City a "Do Not Knock Registry" ("Registry") and is authorized to
contact individuals on the Registry to distribute "Do Not Knock" stickers to
them at no cost to the City or the individuals and contact individuals to
update the list each year.
      (3)   Any person in lawful possession and occupancy of any residence,
house, apartment or other dwelling in the City may request the City or NOPEC to
place and maintain his or her residence, house, apartment or other dwelling on
the Registry by submitting a request on form(s) supplied by the City, or by
submitting a request online at www.blocktheknock.com or at a Block the Knock
community event, which shall contain the following information:
         A.   The name and signature of the person completing the form(s),
unless the submission is done electronically;
         B.   The complete address of the residence, house, apartment or other
dwelling to be placed on the Registry;
         C.   A valid email address of the person completing the form(s);
         D.   The date the form was completed;
         E.   A statement that "No Solicitors or Peddlers" shall call at this
address or words of similar import.
      (4)   A residence, house, apartment or other dwelling, after being
lawfully placed on the Registry, shall remain on said registry until the
earliest of any of the following:
         A.   The City or NOPEC receives notice of removal pursuant to division
(e) of this section; or
         B.   The City or NOPEC receives formal notice that the person who
submitted the form pursuant to division (c) of this section is not or is no
longer a lawful possessor and occupant of the premises.
      (5)   Any person in lawful possession and occupancy of any residence,
house, apartment or other dwelling may request the City or NOPEC to remove his
or her residence, house, apartment or other dwelling from the Registry by
submitting a "Notice of Removal" form(s) supplied by the Administrative
Director, or by submitting a request online to www.blocktheknock.com which
shall contain the following information:
         A.   The name and signature of the person completing the form;
         B.   The complete address of the residence, house, apartment or other
dwelling to be removed from the registry;
         C.   The date the form was completed; and
         D.   A statement that the residence be removed from the Registry.
      (6)   A copy of the Registry shall be made available for public
inspection at all times during normal business hours at the office of the
Administrative Director of the City and shall be given to every solicitor and/
or canvasser.
   (c)   As set forth above in division (b) of this section, each solicitor
and/or canvasser shall be provided with a list of those residences whose owners
or occupants have requested of the City, in writing, that such residence not be
canvassed and/or solicited, and such solicitor or canvasser may not canvass
and/or solicit at a residence on the list. This list shall be compiled and
maintained by NOPEC so long as NOPEC agrees to do so and if NOPEC or another
third party designated by the City no longer compiles this list, then the
Administrative Director shall then continue to maintain and compile this list.
The City shall post signs at its borders that notify solicitors and/or
canvassers that such a list is on file with the Administrative Director and
that solicitors and/or canvassers are prohibited from canvassing persons on the
list.
(Ord. 2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03; Ord. 2018-O-33. Passed 11-13-18.)
   850.03   CANVASSING OR SOLICITATION IN VIOLATION OF NOTICE.
   No person shall go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any
door, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner
calculated to attract the attention of any occupant of such premises for the
purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in
canvassing, as defined in Section 850.01, in defiance of the notice exhibited
at the residence or place of business or in violation of the no solicitation
list in accordance with the provisions of Section 850.02. Whoever violates this
section is guilty of trespass.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03; Ord.2003-O-11. Passed 7-22-03.)
   850.04   SOLICITATIONS PERMITTED ONLY DURING CERTAIN HOURS.
   (a)   No person shall go upon any residential premises and ring the
doorbell, or rap or knock on the door, or create any sound in a manner
calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of the residence for the
purpose of engaging in or attempting to engage in a home solicitation
transaction before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m.
   (b)   Division (a) of this section shall not apply to a visit to the
premises as a result of a request or an appointment made by the occupant.
   (c)   A person shall not contact by telephone the occupant of a residence
for the purpose of engaging in or attempting to engage in a home solicitation
transaction before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any day, Monday through
Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or any State or Federal holiday.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03; Ord.2003-O-11. Passed 7-22-03.)
   850.05   CANVASSING FOR CHARITABLE OR RELIGIOUS PURPOSES; INTERSTATE/
INTRASTATE COMMERCE; REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall act as a canvasser for charitable or religious
purposes or as a door-to-door salesperson in interstate/intrastate commerce in
the City without first having registered as such with the Safety Director or
his or her designated representative. The Safety Director or his or her
designated representative shall issue a registration certificate to each
applicant and such certificate shall be prominently displayed on the person of
the registrant at all times when engaged in such canvassing, solicitation or
sales and shall be shown, on request, to any police officer or any person from
whom a request for contribution or offer to sell is made. Each canvasser or
solicitor shall provide a receipt indicating tax exempt status under Section
501 of the Federal Internal Revenue Code if requested to do so by the person
making a contribution or purchase. Such receipt shall show the name of the
organization, the amount of the contribution and the date, and shall be signed
by the canvasser or solicitor.
   (b)   No registration is required under Section 850.05(a) for those
organizations that are defined in Section 850.01(a)(5), (6), and (7).
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.06   INFORMATION REQUIRED FOR REGISTRATION.
   Each applicant for a certificate of registration shall, within five days of
application therefor, furnish the Safety Director or his or her authorized
representative with the following information on forms provided by the City:
   (a)   The name, age, Social Security number and physical description of the
applicant;
   (b)   A complete permanent and local address of the applicant along with the
Social Security number or the tax identification number of the applicant's
employer;
   (c)   The name and address of the person, firm, corporation or association
for whom or which the canvassing, soliciting or peddling is presently being
made and any other person, firm, corporation, or association for whom or which
the applicant has solicited during the past three years;
   (d)   A general description of the nature of the business and the goods,
services or wares to be sold, or a description that is otherwise sufficient to
identify the subject matter of the canvassing, soliciting or peddling in which
the applicant will engage;
   (e)   The names of all other municipalities in which the applicant has
conducted canvassing, soliciting or peddling activities during the past 12
months;
   (f)   A statement as to whether the applicant has complied with the
requirements of Ohio R.C. Chapter 1716 pertaining to charitable solicitations,
if applicable;
   (g)   A statement as to whether the applicant has ever had a permit revoked,
including the time and place of such revocation;
   (h)   A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a
felony violation or a misdemeanor violation involving moral turpitude,
including the time and place of such conviction;
   (i)   The proposed dates and times of the canvassing, solicitation or
peddling;
   (j)   The make, model, year, color and license plate number of automobiles
used by the applicant during the period of canvassing, solicitation or peddling
within the City, and the number of the applicant's driver's license and the
state of issuance of such license;
   (k)   Two photographs of the applicant of appropriate size (approximately
two inches by two inches), one of which shall be attached at all times to the
certificate and the other of which shall be for the records of the Police
Department; and
   (l)   The City income tax form which shall be filled out and filed with the
application.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.07   ISSUANCE OF REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE; TRANSFERS; DURATION.
   (a)   Issuance of Certificate. Not more than ten working days after
completion of the application form provided for in Section 850.06, and upon
payment of a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00), except that no fee shall be
required from those persons excluded herein or from a charitable, religious or
educational organization, as defined in Ohio R.C. 2915.01(H), (I), and (J), the
Safety Director or his or her authorized representative shall, except as
otherwise provided herein, issue a certificate of registration to each
applicant, unless it is determined by the Safety Director or his or her
authorized representative:
      (1)   That the applicant has misrepresented his or her identity or
intention, or made a false, misleading or deceptive statement in providing the
information required under Section 850.06; or
      (2)   That the applicant has been convicted, during five years preceding
the date of application, of a felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude or force or violence.
   (b)   Transfers; Duration. The certificate of registration issued hereunder
shall not be transferred or assigned or used by any other person other than the
one to whom it is issued and it shall be valid for a period of six months.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.08   DISPLAY OF REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE; RETURN; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   Each registrant shall prominently display on his or her person the
registration certificate at all times when in the City and shall exhibit it to
any resident or Municipal official upon request. At the conclusion of the
period for which the registration certificate was issued, the registration
certificate shall be returned to the Safety Director or his or her designee.
   (b)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to solicitations
conducted only among the members of the entity conducting the canvassing or to
solicitations in the form of collections or contributions at the regular
assemblies, meeting or services of any established charitable or religious
organization.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.09   REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATES.
   (a)   A certificate of registration issued under this chapter shall be
revoked by the Safety Director or his or her designee for any of the following
causes:
      (1)   It is subsequently determined that the registrant providing false,
misleading or deceptive information in completing the application set forth in
Section 850.06, or has violated any of the provisions of this chapter;
      (2)   The registrant is convicted of a felony violation or a misdemeanor
violation involving moral turpitude; or
      (3)   The registrant is convicted of a violation of any provision of this
chapter.
   (b)   Written notice shall be given to the registrant in person or by
certified mail immediately upon such revocation.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.10   DOOR-TO-DOOR SALES IN INTERSTATE/INTRASTATE COMMERCE; PEDDLERS;
LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (a)   License Required; Fee.
      (1)   No person shall act as a door-to-door salesperson in interstate/
intrastate commerce in the City, calling at residences or places of business
without the invitation or previous consent of the owners or occupants thereof,
without first having secured from the Safety Director or his or her designated
representative a license therefor. The fee for such license shall be as
follows:
         A.   For one day:         $15.00
         B.   For one week:         $30.00
         C.   For one year:         $75.00
      (2)   No peddler shall sell or offer for sale in the City any goods,
merchandise or services without first having secured from the Safety Director
or his or her designated representative a license therefor. The fee for such
license shall be as follows:
Fee
   Nature of Operation      Week      Month      Year
   Truck or other
   street vehicle         $30.00      $60.00      $90.00
   Pushcart         $30.00      $50.00      $75.00
   Carried door-to-door      $30.00      $50.00      $75.00
      (3)   All fees collected shall be paid into the General Revenue Fund.
   (b)   License Application; Contents. An application for a license for a
door-to-door salesperson in interstate/intrastate commerce or for a peddler
shall be made upon a form provided by the Safety Director or his or her
designated representative. Each application shall contain, among other
information, the name, address and telephone number of the applicant; the name,
address and telephone number of his or her employer, if any; the nature of the
goods or services for which he or she will take orders or which will be
offered  for sale; the proposed method of operation in the City; and such other
information as the Safety Director may require. A separate license shall be
required for each individual salesperson or peddler even though there may be a
single employer. No person who has been convicted of a misdemeanor involving
moral turpitude or of a felony shall be issued a license as a door-to-door
salesperson in interstate/intrastate commerce or as a peddler. Each applicant
shall submit to fingerprinting for identification purposes.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-20-03.)
   850.11   PEDDLERS OF FROZEN DESSERTS.
   (a)   License Required.
      (1)   A special peddler's license shall be required of all persons who
wish to engage in the sale of various ice creams, custards, frozen sherberts or
other frozen desserts from push carts, wagons or other vehicles.
      (2)   Such license shall be issued to no person under the age of 18
years, and a condition precedent to the issuance of such license shall be a
duly authenticated birth certificate. The applicant shall also obtain, at his
or her own expense, a certificate of health from a physician.
   (b)   Application; Investigation. An application shall be secured from the
Safety Director or his or her designated representative, and after the
requirements of division (a) of this section have been complied with, the
application shall be submitted to the Police Department which shall investigate
the same for the purpose of determining the criminal record of any applicant,
as far as the Department can ascertain such record.
   (c)   Photograph for License.
      (1)   After certification by the Police Department, the applicant shall
return the application to the Safety Director or his or her designated
representative together with a photograph of himself or herself, which
photograph shall be affixed to the license by the Safety Director or his or her
designated representative.
      (2)   The license shall contain a description of the peddler, showing his
or her height, age, weight, color of eyes, and color of hair.
   (d)   License Expiration; Transfer; Fee. A special peddler's license shall
not be transferrable to any other person. The license shall expire on the last
day of each calendar year. The license fee shall be seventy-five dollars
($75.00) per year.
   (e)   Place of Sales to Children. No sales or merchandise shall be made to
children within the area of public streets or roadways. Sales may be made only
within the tree lawn or sidewalk area.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.12   REGULATIONS FOR PERSONS USING VEHICLES.
   (a)   No person soliciting, selling or offering for sale, or traveling about
the City soliciting the purchase of any goods, wares, merchandise or other
articles of value, including food, candy confections, frozen desserts or
beverages shall, when such activities are conducted from a vehicle, do any of
the following:
      (1)   Operate a vehicle when under the age of 18 years;
      (2)   Operate a vehicle at a speed in excess of 15 miles per hour when
cruising neighborhoods or attempting to make a sale;
      (3)   Make a "U" turn on any street;
      (4)   Operate the vehicle backwards in making or attempting to make a
sale;
      (5)   Double park or park in any manner contrary to any law relating to
parking when attempting to make or making a sale;
      (6)   Permit any person except an employee to hang on the vehicle or
permit any person except an employee to ride in or on the vehicle;
      (7)   Refuse to move the vehicle from any street or public place in the
City upon the request of a police officer when, in the opinion of the police
officer, such vehicle is causing traffic congestion or is creating a nuisance;
      (8)   Make or attempt to make a sale within a public park, or within 500
feet of any school, school yard or school playground during the hours when such
school is in regular or special session, or for a period of one-half hour after
the closing of such school;
      (9)   Make or attempt to make a sale within 100 feet of an intersection;
      (10)   Make or attempt to make a sale to any person standing in a street
of the City;
      (11)   Make or attempt to make a sale from a side of a vehicle not
closest to the nearest curb or berm;
      (12)   Cry his wares in a loud voice or use any noise-producing device
other than a soft chime, and the limit of audibility of his voice or chime
shall not be more than 200 feet from the source of such sound, which sound
shall be eliminated whenever the vehicle is stopped for the purpose of selling
or offering to sell such items;
      (13)   Sell or offer for sale food, candy, confections, frozen desserts
or beverages, unless the vehicle is equipped with two red lights on the rear of
such vehicle, positioned not less than six feet above ground, and two yellow
lights on the front of such vehicle, not less than four feet above ground, and
two yellow lights on the top of such vehicle. Each of such lights shall be not
less than seven inches in diameter and shall be connected so as to
intermittently flash when such vehicle is stopped for the purpose of selling or
offering to sell such items. It is hereby declared to be unlawful for such
vehicles to stop unless each of such six lights is operating as required.
      (14)   Sell or offer for sale food, candy, confections, frozen desserts
or beverages, unless the vehicle is equipped with a sign stating, "CAUTION -
CHILDREN" on the front and back of such vehicle. Each sign shall be in letters
at least four inches in height. In addition, each vehicle shall have two side
view mirrors of such design that the driver will be able to see behind and
alongside of the vehicle from his or her position in the driver's seat.
      (15)   Sell or offer for sale food, candy, confections, frozen desserts
or beverages, unless the operator of the vehicle is at all times accompanied by
a responsible adult, whose sole duty it shall be to keep a lookout for and
protect the safety of children and other persons attracted to or proceeding to
or from the location of the vehicle; or
      (16)   Sell or offer to sell goods, wares, merchandise or other articles
of value, including food, candy, confections, frozen desserts or beverages,
without first having in effect a general policy of liability insurance with
limits of not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) per person injured or
property damage proximately by such sale or attempt to sell.
   (b)   Every person referred to division (a) of this section and licensed
under this chapter shall have his photograph attached to his license in his
immediate possession at all times when peddling or soliciting. He shall display
the same upon demand of any police officer of the City or upon demand of any
person to whom he is peddling or soliciting.
   (c)   There shall be no more than three licenses issued under this section
each year and no more than one such license in any event to each business
entity.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
   850.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not more than two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than 30 days, or both, for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord.2003-O-04. Passed 4-22-03.)
CHAPTER 854
Private Security Officers
854.01   Private security officer defined.
854.02   Commission required; qualifications.
854.03   Applications; fingerprints; fees.
854.04   Registration of weapons; certifications.
854.05   Uniforms, badges, etc.
854.06   Liability insurance required.
854.07   Indemnification of City.
854.08   Revocation of commissions.
854.09   Notification of Chief of Police by employers.
854.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Private investigators - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4749
   School guards - see TRAF.
404.06
   854.01   PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICER DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "private security officer" means any person, not a
member of the Police or Fire Department of the City, who is employed as a
security officer, watchman, security guard or in any similar capacity and who
carries or may carry a firearm.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.02   COMMISSION REQUIRED; QUALIFICATIONS.
   No person shall act as a private security officer, or hold himself or
herself out as a private security officer, in the City, unless he or she has
first been commissioned by the Chief of Police. Such commission shall be valid
for one year from the date of issuance. In order to qualify for such
commission, the applicant shall:
   (a)   Be at least eighteen years of age;
   (b)   Be of sound physique, with good eyesight and not subject to vertigo,
heart trouble or any other infirmity of body or mind which might render him or
her unfit for the safe carrying out of the duties of such commission. Each
applicant shall supply an affidavit to the Chief of Police with his or her
application that he or she is free from any and all of the infirmities
mentioned in this subsection.
   (c)   Be of good moral character and not addicted to the use of intoxicating
liquors and/or drugs; and
   (d)   Register with the Chief of Police and apply for his or her commission
prior to beginning duty in the City.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.03   APPLICATIONS; FINGERPRINTS; FEES.
   (a)   In order to receive a commission as a private security officer, an
applicant shall submit the following information on such forms as are
designated by the Chief of Police;
      (1)   Name;
      (2)   Age;
      (3)   Social Security number;
      (4)   Current address and all other addresses at which the applicant has
resided in the past five years;
      (5)   Height, weight and color of eyes and hair;
      (6)   Place of birth;
      (7)   Place of previous employment;
      (8)   Whether single or married;
      (9)   Whether he or she has ever been arrested or convicted of a felony
or misdemeanor;
      (10)   Whether his or her driver's license has ever been revoked and, if
so, for what cause;
      (11)   A photostatic copy of the certificates issued by the Ohio Peace
Officers Training Council for any person that will be carrying a handgun or
other weapon while employed as a private security officer in the City, unless
he or she has completed twenty years of active duty as a peace officer, as
defined in Ohio R.C. 109.71.
      (12)   The names and addresses of two character references; and
      (13)   A waiver of certain rights and liabilities.
   (b)   Each such application shall be signed by the applicant and accompanied
by three unretouched photographs of the applicant, of such size as the Chief of
Police may, by rule, provide. The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to
conduct an investigation into the background of each applicant. No applicant
shall be registered if, upon investigation, the Chief of Police reasonably
determines that such applicant is not a person of suitable character.
   (c)   Each applicant shall be fingerprinted. The fingerprint record,
together with a copy of the application, shall be made a part of the permanent
police records.
   (d)   An application fee shall be charged in the amount of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per individual application and fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
security company.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.04   REGISTRATION OF WEAPONS; CERTIFICATION.
   Any handgun or other weapon that will be carried by a private security
officer shall be registered with the Chief of Police and subject to such tests
as the Chief prescribes. No private security officer shall carry a handgun or
other weapon while on duty as a private security officer unless he or she has
first obtained a certificate pursuant to Ohio R.C. 109.78 or completed twenty
years of active duty as a peace officer, as defined in Ohio R.C. 109.71.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.05   UNIFORMS, BADGES, ETC.
   (a)   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to prescribe such uniform,
badge and/or distinguishing uniform marks for a private security officer as he
may see fit in order to distinguish such private security officer from a
regular police officer of the City.
   (b)   No person who is not a member of the Police or Fire Department of the
City shall wear a uniform, cap, badge or buttons similar to, or in imitation
of, the official uniform in use at the time by the members of such Departments.
The use of police blue is prohibited unless specifically authorized by the
Chief of Police.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.06   LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   Every private security officer shall provide, along with his or her
application for registration as a private security officer, proof that he or
she is insured by a policy or policies of comprehensive general liability
insurance in an amount of at least five hundred thousand dollars ($500,00) for
any and all claims for bodily injury and property damage arising out of his or
her activities as a private security officer or activities incidental or
related thereto. Such policy of insurance shall name the City as an additional
insured thereon.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.07   INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY.
   Every private security officer, his or her employer and the owner of the
premises where the private security officer is to perform his or her duties
shall agree to indemnify and hold harmless the City and its agents, servants
and employees against any and all claims arising out of such officer's
activities as a private security officer or activities incidental or related
thereto.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.08   REVOCATION OF COMMISSIONS.
   The Chief of Police may revoke the commission of a private security officer
upon a showing of good cause therefor.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.09   NOTIFICATION OF CHIEF OF POLICE BY EMPLOYERS.
   No person shall employ a private security firm, private security officer,
night watchman or guard in the City without first advising the Chief of Police
and determining that such firm, officer, night watchman or guard is
commissioned by the City.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)
   854.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on a first offense and a misdemeanor of the first degree on a
second or subsequent offense. Punishment shall be as provided in Section
698.02. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord.80-O-17. Passed 7-8-80.)

CHAPTER 864
Special Events
864.01   Definitions.
864.02   General authority and duty of Chief of Police; issuance of permits by
other departments.
864.03   Interpretation.
864.04   Permit required; fee; application; conditions; deposit; issuance.
864.05   Notice to abutting landowners.
864.06   Indemnification.
864.07   Denial or revocation of permits.
864.08   Appeal from denial or revocation of a permit.
864.09   Offenses.
864.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Obstruction and special uses of public ways - see TRAF.
Ch. 412
   Safety of crowds - see GEN. OFF. 636.18
   Disorderly conduct; obstructing public ways - see GEN. OFF. 648.04(a)(4),
660.10
   Disturbing a lawful meeting - see GEN. OFF. 648.05
   Smoking in places of public assembly - see GEN. OFF. 660.19
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 804
   Parades and open air meetings - see B.R. & T. Ch. 846
   864.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Applicant" means a person who has filed a written application for a
special event permit.
   (b)   "Chief of Police" means the Chief of Police of the City of Mentor-on-
the-Lake, or his or her designated agent.
   (c)   "City" means the City of Mentor-on-the-Lake, Ohio.
   (d)   "Demonstration" means a public display of the attitude of assembled
persons toward a person, cause, issue or other matter.
   (e)   "Person" means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation,
association or other legal entity.
   (f)   "Special event" means a temporary event or gathering, including a
special event parade, using either private or public property, in which the
estimated numbers of participants exceeds fifteen during any day of the event
and which involves one or more of the following activities, except when the
activity is for construction or house-moving purposes only:
      (1)   Closing a public street;
      (2)   Blocking or restriction of public property;
      (3)   Sale of merchandise, food or beverages on public property outside
the central business district, or on private property where otherwise
prohibited by ordinance;
      (4)   Erection of a tent on public property, or on private property where
otherwise prohibited by ordinance;
      (5)   Installation of a stage, bandshell, trailer, van, portable
building, grandstand or bleachers on public property, or on private property
where otherwise prohibited by ordinance;
      (6)   Placement of portable toilets on public property, or on private
property where otherwise prohibited by ordinance; or
      (7)   Placement of temporary "No Parking" signs in a public right-of-way.
   (g)   "Special event parade" means the assembly of three or more persons
whose gathering is for the common design of travelling or marching in
procession from one location to any other location for the purpose of
advertising, promoting, celebrating or commemorating a thing, person, date or
event that is not directly related to the expression of feelings and beliefs on
current political, religious or social issues.
   (h)   "Special event permit" means written approval from the City to hold a
special event.
(Ord.90-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.02   GENERAL AUTHORITY AND DUTY OF CHIEF OF POLICE; ISSUANCE OF PERMITS
BY OTHER DEPARTMENTS.
   (a)   The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by
the Chief of Police.
   (b)   The Chief of Police, after review of the application, shall make a
recommendation to the Mayor to issue the permit or to deny the permit, and the
Mayor has the authority to issue a special event permit that authorizes one or
more of the activities described in Section 864.01(f) when requirements of this
chapter have been met.
   (c)   Application for a special event permit authorizes other appropriate
City departments and/or officials to issue any necessary and proper permits for
the activities described in Section 864.01(f) in locations where the activity
would otherwise be prohibited by ordinance.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.03   INTERPRETATION.
   The provisions of this chapter are cumulative of all City ordinances. Tent
permits, building permits, electrical permits, food establishment permits,
alcoholic beverage licenses and all other permits and licenses required by
ordinance or other law for specific activities to be conducted in conjunction
with or as part of the special event must be applied for separately in
accordance with the applicable ordinance or law.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.04   PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE; APPLICATION; CONDITIONS; DEPOSIT; ISSUANCE.
   (a)   A person desiring to hold a special event shall apply for a special
event permit by filing with the Chief of Police a written application upon a
form provided for that purpose. Each application must be accompanied by a
nonrefundable application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which fee may
be waived or reduced by the Mayor. An application must be filed not less than
ninety days before the special event is to begin. The Mayor may waive the
ninety-day filing requirement if he or she determines that the application can
be processed in less than ninety days, taking into consideration the number and
types of permits required to be issued in conjunction with the special event
permit.
   (b)   An application must contain the following information:
      (1)   The name, address and telephone number of the applicant and of any
other persons responsible for the conduct of the special event;
      (2)   A description of the special event and requested dates and hours of
operation for the event;
      (3)   The estimated number of persons to participate in the special
event;
      (4)   A sketch showing the area or route to be used during the special
event, along with proposed structures, tents, fences, barricades, signs,
banners and restroom facilities;
      (5)   Provisions for parking with a designation of where "No Parking"
signs will be used;
      (6)   Details of how the applicant proposes to provide security and
traffic control;
      (7)   The time and location of street closings, if any are requested;
      (8)   Details of the sale of merchandise or the sale or serving of food
or alcoholic beverages at the special event, designating any street vendors or
peddlers involved;
      (9)   A description of animals to be used in the special event, if any;
      (10)   A detailed plan as to how the applicant will clean up the area of
the special event after it has ended, whether on public property or private
property; and
      (11)   Proof that the applicant possesses or is able to obtain all
licenses and permits required by these Codified Ordinances or other City
ordinances or by State law for the conduct of the special event and written
proof that the applicant has permission from the private property owner.
   (c)   Upon receipt of the completed application, the Chief of Police shall
forward a copy of the application to the Administrative Director of the City of
Mentor-on-the-Lake and said Administrative Director shall review the
application and return it, with any comments, to the Chief of Police within ten
working days of receipt.
   (d)   The Administrative Director and the Chief of Police may prescribe
licenses and permits required by other City ordinances or applicable law,
restrictions, regulations, costs for City services, safeguards and other
conditions necessary for the safe and orderly conduct of a special event, to be
incorporated into the permit before issuance.  (Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   (e)   A cash deposit shall be paid to the City in the amount of the
estimated costs that the City will incur as a result of the special event.  The
Chief of Police and the Administrative Director shall determine the amount of
the cash deposit.  The cash deposit must be received by the Chief of Police not
less than five days before the date of the special event as shown on the
special event permit. All or part of the fees required to be reimbursed to the
City as a result of a special event may be waived by resolution of the City
Council.
   (f)   After reviewing the application, the comments of the Administrative
Director and the recommendation of the Chief of Police, the Mayor shall issue
the special event permit unless denial is required by Section 864.07. A special
event permit will be issued for a period not to exceed three consecutive days.
A separate permit is required for each three-day period during which a special
event will be conducted.
(Ord.94-O-07.  Passed 6-14-94.)
   864.05   NOTICE TO ABUTTING LANDOWNERS.
   (a)   An applicant for a permit to hold a special event in which the
estimated number of participants exceeds 500 during any day of the special
event shall, at least thirty days before the special event begins, deliver
notice to all owners or occupants of real property abutting the boundaries of
the area in which the special event will be conducted, including all owners or
occupants of real property abutting the route of a progressive event such as a
marathon. An applicant for a permit to hold a special event parade is excluded
from the requirements of this section.
   (b)   The notice must be delivered to the address of each abutting property.
   (c)   The notice must state that an application for a special event permit
has been filed for the location and that interested persons may contact the
Chief of Police with their comments.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.06   INDEMNIFICATION.
   An applicant for a special event permit must execute a written agreement to
indemnify the City and its officers and employees against all claims of injury
or damage to persons or property, whether public or private, arising out of the
special event. 
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.07   DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF PERMITS.
   (a)   The Chief of Police shall deny a special event permit if:
      (1)   A special event permit has been granted for another special event
at the same place and time;
      (2)   The proposed special event will unreasonably disrupt the orderly
flow of traffic and no reasonable means of re-routing traffic or otherwise
meeting traffic needs is available;
      (3)   The applicant fails to adequately provide for:
         A.   The protection of event participants;
         B.   Maintenance of public order in and around the special event
location;
         C.   Crowd security, taking into consideration the size and character
of the event; or
         D.   Emergency and public safety vehicle access;
      (4)   The applicant fails to comply with, or the proposed special event
will violate, a City ordinance or other applicable law, unless the prohibited
conduct or activity would be allowed under this chapter;
      (5)   The applicant makes a false statement of material fact on the
application for a special event permit;
      (6)   The applicant fails to provide proof that he or she possesses or is
able to obtain a license or permit required by City ordinance or other
applicable law for the conduct of all activities included as part of the
special event;
      (7)   The applicant has had a special event permit revoked within the
preceding fourteen months;
      (8)   The applicant has committed, within the preceding fourteen months,
two or more violations of a condition or provision of a special event permit of
this chapter; or
      (9)   The applicant fails to pay any outstanding costs owed to the City
for a past special event.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall revoke a special event permit if:
      (1)   The applicant fails to comply with, or the special event is in
violation of, a condition or provision of the special event permit, an
ordinance of the City or any other applicable law; or
      (2)   The permit holder made a false statement of material fact on an
application for a special event permit.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.08   APPEAL FROM DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF A PERMIT.
   If the Chief of Police denies the issuance of a permit or revokes a permit,
pursuant to the powers granted to him or her in Section 864.07, then the Chief
of Police shall send to the applicant or permit holder by certified mail,
return receipt requested, at the address listed in the application for the
permit, written notice of the denial or revocation and of the right to an
appeal. The applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the Chief of
Police to the Mayor of the City of Mentor-on-the-Lake within five working days
of the date when the notice is received by the applicant or permit holder.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.09   OFFENSES.
   (a)   A person commits an offense if he or she:
      (1)   Commences or conducts a special event without a special event
permit; or
      (2)   Fails to comply with any requirement or provision of a special
event permit or of this chapter.
   (b)   A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an
offense under this section.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
   864.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, including a requirement of a special event permit governing fire
safety, zoning or public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse,
shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each offense. 
Whoever violates or fails to comply with any other provision of this chapter,
including a requirement of a special event permit, shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.  Each day or part of day that
a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord.92-O-11.  Passed 10-13-92.)
